summary: This is an email chain from August 2020 regarding the transfer of a large, non-searchable draft report from the Department of Justice's Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR). The report concerns OPR's investigation into the handling of the Jeffrey Epstein matter by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida from 2006-2008. The correspondence involves technical assistance requests between US Attorney's Office personnel and a contractor to make the document searchable.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The OPR draft report concerns the handling of the Jeffrey Epstein matter by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida in 2006-2008.

events.title: Handling of Epstein Matter by SD Florida
events.description: The time period investigated by the Department of Justice's Office of Professional Responsibility regarding how the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida handled the Jeffrey Epstein case.

events.title: OPR Sends Draft Report to SDNY
events.description: The DOJ's Office of Professional Responsibility transmits its draft report and a cover letter regarding the Epstein matter to the Acting U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

events.title: Technical Issues with OPR Report
events.description: Personnel at the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York correspond with a contractor to resolve technical issues with the large, non-searchable OPR draft report attachment.

locations: 930 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW â€” Room 3266, Washington, D.C. 20530
keyFacts: The Department of Justice's Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) conducted an investigation into how the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida handled the Jeffrey Epstein matter from 2006 to 2008.
A draft of the OPR report was sent to the Acting U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York on August 6, 2020.
The attached OPR draft report was a large file (over 380 pages) that was not searchable, causing technical difficulties for the recipients.
The correspondence shows internal DOJ processes for handling sensitive investigative reports related to the Epstein case.
